tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo-rsyslog-re.message: If looking for an example, we did an action plugin for the firewall rules to not hit the overhead james is refering to.

i'll have to see how this gets used from t-h-t, but in general we should try and avoid looping over lists one item at a time per node.

The task overhead is very costly, even for simple tasks. Consider 500 nodes, with a list of 10 items...5000 tasks.

You should consider using an action plugin to apply the list in bulk if possible, to keep the task count equivalent to the node count.
Makes sense, will have a look and do some more work on that patch. Thanks for the advice!

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
What does "Removing this option" means on this context?

My understanding is that having TLS termination at the openstack services generates the need of cumbersome override file. Removing the TLS termination from openstack services will make the overrides smaller, as you stated after.
Is this test still pending? If not please update accordingly

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I don't see it related to any bug or story.

It would be mandatory to have the PENDING test results to ensure that there is no leftovers on the code causing issues when https is enabled with Openstack applied.

Would also like to hear some other opinions on terminating TLS at ingress and not at the openstack services.
Please, WIP this review until all tests are done.

I am deeply concerned about this patch since I think this opens attack vectors on a remote edge scenario. If the services are not talking TLS in between the controllers and an attacker have access to a remote edge and plug a sniffer on the cable, wouldn't he be able to have access to information exchanged between the OS services or even take control of them since the API keys would be in plain sight?

`I think this opens attack vectors on a remote edge scenario` this does not open because on the first place it is not possible to have https enabled on openstack services with the current centos based containers that we have, openstack-helm only supports tls using debian based containers.

`If the services are not talking TLS in between the controllers` they are talking TLS between themselves as they only talk to each other via public ingress

ex. openstack volume list command from inside the controller will perform the following request:

```
REQ: curl -g -i -X GET https://cinder.lcavalcante.com/v3/dfcf9553c75d4e5fa1efcb779f3adad5/volumes/detail -H "Accept: application/json" -H "User-Agent: python-cinderclient" -H "X-Auth-Token: {SHA256}a6b14109d61ea70081342d083133fe8da25ffc02c2f4a8f83001a59837e9ea5f"
Starting new HTTPS connection (1): cinder.lcavalcante.com
https://cinder.lcavalcante.com:443 "GET /v3/dfcf9553c75d4e5fa1efcb779f3adad5/volumes/detail HTTP/1.1" 200 15
```

This patch does however remove tls from rabbitmq and mariadb, this is a more serious issue, however I am not confident that current openstack-helm and openstack-helm-infra supports production level openstack with mariadb in TLS mode. Furthermore, from the way everything is redirected in StarlingX I do see too many performance and stability issues using both of them with tls enabled. Disclaimer I did not test with either only mairiadb tls or rabbitmq activated, but with both of them on the system is not  usable.

TL;DR:

* openstack-helm-infra/files/0020-Fix-tls-in-openstack-helm-infra.patch does not change any behaviour and only help us reduce the size of the override file (makes it possible to use the same overrides we used for stx 5.0)

* openstack-helm-infra/files/0021 and openstack-helm-infra/files/0022 deals with the apply bug https://launchpad.net/bugs/1960354 that happened after we rebased openstack-helm and mariadb and/or rabbitmq with tls on does not work for StarlingX

ovn_octavia_provider/helper.py.message: Now you're applying this external_id to all router interface ports. Before, it was to all ports of type == 'router'. What happens if you apply this patch to an already existing setup? Do you need to clear up the external_ids from those ports that shouldn't have it? (maybe in some sort of maintenance task or one-off at startup?)

I also think it should be ok even for existing LBs as router ports already should have this device_owner stored there so we can always check it when e.g. new member will be added to the existing (old) LB.

Disregard my comment, you're not writing any external_ids. I guess that my question has more to do with existing LBs, do we need some sort of update path to update the LR/LB associations for existing LBs?

I don't think so. This is only ensuring we only look for the ports we are interested in (the ones with DEVICE_ONWER_ROUTER_INTF). For existing LBs, the loop would check more ports, but it will select the same anyway. Also, initial problem of this is when VIPs are on the provider network, and that provider network is dual-stack. In that case there are router ports (like the router_gateway port) which has 2 IPs and break the IPNetwork casting. Thus, there was not option before to have those type of loadbalancers as it was ERRORing due to this problem.

Seems we were working on similar issue. I should have check this before as I opened https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1959903 which looks exactly the same.

I created an slightly different fix for it https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ovn-octavia-provider/+/827670. The approach is slightly different, I'm ensuring that we only look for the type of ports we really need (DEVICE_OWNER_ROUTER_INTF), which cannot have 2 ips (ipv4 and ipv6). Perhaps we can add in that patch also this protection in case that is possible in the future.

There is one important difference. In my patch I ensure when the members are added, the lr is also considered and the loadbalancer added to it. Otherwise, the loadbalancer will go to ACTIVE but there will be no connectivity to it.

Adding -1 to ensure discussion about how to proceed

which doesnt mock dsc_connect_volume function.

os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py.message: no need for this added level of abstraction, just change the callsites to call get_host_nqn() directly. Larger patch but cleaner code.
ok, I removed it.

-1: I believe that for this connector, this function was only used in get_connector_properties(), so you no longer need to define this function at all.

The lightos driver [0] is the one currently calling an out-of-interface function on the lightos connector, not on this connector.  So I think this function isn't needed any more.

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/638688b5bf47847369070f050ef6755972015927/cinder/volume/drivers/lightos.py#L817
Done
I agree with Muli.

Gorka's suggestion was that this function should go into os_brick/utils.py.  You could expose it here, but the advantage to it being in utils is that then it's obviously common code, and people will be more aware of that when refactoring happens.  Plus, this file and lightos.py already import os_brick.utils.

The filenames are just there to organize the privileged functions for developers.  Any of the os_brick code can import and call any of the functions, so you don't need to worry about the file name.

I think it makes sense to keep the privileged function in nvmeof.py because it's an nvme kind of thing, and in utils.py you can do

  from os_brick.privileged import nvmeof as priv_nvme

and then call priv_nvme.create_hostnqn() from within your utility function.

(Of course, other reviewers may have different opinions.)

I agree, having it in utils seems like easier to understand it's common code as well as make it harder for someone to do a refactoring in nvmeof.py and break the lightos.py connector.

Alternatively we could create a os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvme_common.py file where we put the common things between these 2 connectors.
Its in os_brick/utils.py as requested - anything else is needed?

Let's keep Gorka's suggestion in mind as development continues on the nvmeof and lightos connectors.  You should make a point of reviewing changes to the nvmeof connector, and people working on that one should make a point of reviewing yours.

my thought of writing it here was - well its an nvme operation and the file is called nvmeof - so it made sense for me.
also the function use privileged access and was not sure how utils.py will handle it.
should I add a "utils.py" under priviliged dir?
That's fine as far as I'm concerned ... in utils for now, and into a nvme_common module if there turns out to be more code that could be re-used.

While running this test with other iscsi devices in pre production we found the following issues when trying to create multiple instances at the same time. Up to 3 instances, it works fine but has more than 3 instances found the following errors.

cinder_http_retries = 30
cinder_state_transition_timeout = 3000

I'd really like to see some parity for systemd behavior post-install/pre-bootstrap.

On CentOS, I see:

localhost:/etc/systemd# systemctl status fm-api.service
● fm-api.service - Fault Management REST API Service
   Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/fm-api.service; enabled; vendor preset: disabled)
   Active: failed (Result: exit-code) since Tue 2022-01-18 20:35:39 UTC; 1 weeks 1 days ago
  Process: 9557 ExecStart=/etc/rc.d/init.d/fm-api start (code=exited, status=1/FAILURE)
 Main PID: 9557 (code=exited, status=1/FAILURE)

localhost:/etc/systemd# systemctl status fminit.service
● fminit.service - StarlingX Fault Management Initialization
   Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/fminit.service; disabled; vendor preset: disabled)
   Active: inactive (dead)

On Debian I see with these changes:

sysadmin@localhost:~$ systemctl status fm-api.service
● fm-api.service - Fault Management REST API Service
     Loaded: loaded (/lib/systemd/system/fm-api.service; enabled; vendor preset: enabled)
     Active: failed (Result: exit-code) since Thu 2022-01-27 01:51:39 UTC; 1min 13s ago
    Process: 1803 ExecStart=/etc/init.d/fm-api start (code=exited, status=1/FAILURE)
   Main PID: 1803 (code=exited, status=1/FAILURE)
        CPU: 1.155s

sysadmin@localhost:~$ systemctl status fminit.service
● fminit.service - StarlingX Fault Management Initialization
     Loaded: loaded (/lib/systemd/system/fminit.service; enabled; vendor preset: enabled)
     Active: failed (Result: exit-code) since Thu 2022-01-27 01:49:37 UTC; 3min 25s ago
    Process: 542 ExecStart=/etc/init.d/fminit start (code=exited, status=0/SUCCESS)
   Main PID: 675 (code=exited, status=255/EXCEPTION)
        CPU: 40ms

Under CentOS we have the follows defaults for systemd behavior:

localhost:~$ ls -l /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/*
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root  264 Nov 23  2018 /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/85-display-manager.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 3872 Nov 23  2018 /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/90-default.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root  928 May 10  2021 /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/90-systemd.preset
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root   10 May 10  2021 /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/99-default-disable.preset

localhost:~$ rpm -q --whatprovides /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/*
centos-release-7-6.1810.2.el7.centos.x86_64
centos-release-7-6.1810.2.el7.centos.x86_64
systemd-219-78.el7_9.3.tis.12.x86_64
systemd-219-78.el7_9.3.tis.12.x86_64

Under Debian:

sysadmin@localhost:~$ ls -l /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset
total 4
-rw-r--r-- 3 root root 1327 Jan  1  1970 90-systemd.preset

Under CentOS we disable services by default.

localhost:~$ cat /usr/lib/systemd/system-preset/99-default-disable.preset
disable *

We should do the same under Debian, so only specific services are enabled via the rules file, ansible, or puppet.

The spec file for fm-rest-api, specifically enables the service, where fm-init is merely installs the service file. We should be following suit:

 fm-rest-api.spec: /bin/systemctl enable fm-api.service >/dev/null 2>&1

I suspect we'll have to revisit some of the recent service changes that we just made to make sure expected behavior lines up

Since this a change that came from original systemd CentOS package, we need to test the preset files, possibly, as pointed by you, start by 99-default-disable.preset first, and if not achieved, check the others. Since this is something not specific to this service, but to all, I think would be better to have a separate task under the same storyboard and proceed with this one.
I'll update the review shortly with a new dependency on the new debian-compt package, them, it should be good for now

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/host_vars/b.message:
spelling, grammar errors

How about?

The following parameters (in dictionary format) are used to configure Kubernetes control plane components, the kubelet as well as networking respsectively:
apiserver_extra_args: {}
controllermanager_extra_args: {}

kubelet_extra_args: {}
kubelet_configurations: {}

networking_configurations: {}

By default the system is bootstrapped with a set of default values e.g.

apiserver_extra_args:
  default-unreachable-toleration-seconds: "30"
  feature-gates: "SCTPSupport=true,TTLAfterFinished=true

controllermanager_extra_args:
  pod-eviction-timeout: '30s'
  feature-gates: "TTLAfterFinished=true"

kubelet_configurations: {}
  nodeStatusUpdateFrequency: "4s"
  featureGates:
    HugePageStorageMediumSize: true

networking_configurations:
  dnsDomain: 'cluster.local'

Please refer to the official documentation for more details on these overwritable parameters.
I don't think these parameters are meant to be overwritable.
Did you mean to move these default parameters to the role vars file instead? Not sure why we now document both networking_configurations and networking_configurations_defaults in this file.
No parameters in this file should reference a parameter that is not (or should not be) in this file.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: Are these parameters supposed to be overwritable parameters? If they are, they must be included in default.yml and related documentation. If they are not, please remove.

In this case they must be added to bootstrap default.yml file. You can also remove these set_fact tasks here and use default filter where they are referenced e.g.

apiserver_extra_args: "{{ apiserver_extra_args_defaults | combine(apiserver_extra_args|default({})) }}"

Need also a task to update StartlingX documentation so the users know what k8s bootstrap parameters can be customized.

Yes, the parameters are overwritable. The user can set on or more of these dictionaries optionally from /home/sysadmin/localhost.yaml, this file takes precedence over the defaults values.

The variables are defined in this block because it is mandatory that they exist to perform the combination with the default dictionaries. Anyway I have move these definitions to https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/ansible-playbooks/+/826532/8/playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/bootstrap/bringup-essential-services/vars/main.yml. -1: This is not technically correct, because if force is True then we should continue with the dsc_disconnect_volume regardless, and only after it if we failed the flush and ignore_errors is not True should we raise the exception. 

        :param force: Whether to forcefully disconnect even if flush fails.
        :param ignore_errors: When force is True, this will decide whether to
                              ignore errors or raise an exception once finished
                              the operation.  Default is False.

Gorka, just to make sure - we checked nvmeof.py connector (closest to the LightOS connector) and it completely ignores force. Is force actually used/passed by upper levels and we should follow the comment you quote above verbatim?
Done

In some cases, e.g., when 'blockdev' isn't found, this can leave us with dangling dsc files. I think we should remove the dsc file regardless of any errors thrown by flush_device_io. So we have two options: either we remember those errors and raise them if ignore_errors is False, but only after having removed the dsc file, or we just ignore any errors thrown by flush_device_io, which I think is the more reasonable approach.

We narrowed down the behavior to:
if force is False - raise errors as usual
if force is True - don't raise errors so that cinder will do the ACL update. Errors here means either a problem with the flush (e.g., blockdev is not found) or with deleting the dsc file (RO FS?) and neither justifies not updating the ACL to remove the access to the volume, i.e., raising errors from the connector. This has the unfortunate effect of ignoring the 'ignore_errors' flag but it does provide the expected behavior.

That is what should happen if flush fails and force is True, but if force is False and ignore_errors is False as well then in theory we should leave the "dangling dsc file", because Nova shouldn't be calling Cinder to terminate the connection.

That's not the expected behavior.

As defined in the docstring these are two independent flags. Raising exceptions is controlled by the "ignore_errors", and it happens once the method finishes.  When it finishes depends on the "force" flag and whether there were errors or not.

If there are no error or if "force" is set then the method finishes once it has run all the commands, and if there are errors and "force" is not set then the method finishes once it encounters the first error.

You can look at the iSCSI connector for ideas of how to implement this using the `ExceptionChainer` class: https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/blob/e761ab64230faf9b210a1457ceca592a51202fd6/os_brick/initiator/connectors/iscsi.py#L915

Instead of the try except block, can we use the ExceptionChainer as a context manager and perform the flush operation under it since the __exit__ method already calls add_exception[1]
Similar to this[2]

This is more readable for me - any special reason to use context manager?

The ExceptionChainer class is defined in a way that we don't have to call add_exception manually and the context manager performs the work for us. Similar to what we do in file handling while opening a file and the context manager ensures that the file is closed in the end. That would be much cleaner and more pythonic way of writing this IMO. Code consistency is another reason since we use it as a context manager throughout os-brick.

Sorry, I think I explained myself incorrectly.
There are 2 cases:
- We find the vol.id in volumes_model
- We don't find it

If we find the vol.id then volume_model will point to a dictionary that is already in volumes_model, so when we modify the contents of volume_model then we will be returning that information on the method's return.

If we don't find vol.id we create a new dictionary that is NOT stored in volumes_model and is not used for anything because it's lost on the next loop iteration.

For this last case, if we know that volume_model will always be found and its dict will be used, then there is no need to reassign it on L6096 an L6106, because methods _update_replication_properties and _qos_model_update already update the volume_model dictionary, right?

And if it isn't found, then we need to do something with that volume_model value.

Thanks for your insight.

Agreed. Reassignment to volume_model is not required.

The methods _update_replication_properties and _qos_model_update are returning "model_update" dictionary. These methods are used in multiple places. Hence, as suggested by you, I have removed reassignment to volume_model at L6096 and L6106 only.

General comment: After confirming this builds and generates the packages that we need, I support merging this as-is to provide Ceph support for initial integration efforts. We can refactor for maintainability after submission

Notes about contents and permissions:

- Some packages are created and not present as RPMs, namely:
 - libcephfs-jni
 - libcephfs-java
 - libradospp-dev
 - cephfs-shell
 - ceph-resource-agents
To remove them from a build, their corresponding parameter for the 'make' command needs to be changed to OFF, their .install file removed and their declaration in control removed. Parameters:
 - DWITH_CEPHFS_JAVA: libcephfs-jni, libcephfs-java
 - DWITH_CEPHFS_SHELL: cephfs-shell
 - DWITH_OCF: ceph-resource-agents

- Libraries:
Ceph RPMs have permission 755, however they were kept at 644 as it is the standard in debian.
Changing them causes a lintian error shared-library-is-executable.
It can be changed by adding this command to override_dh_fixperms in rules:
`find debian -name "*.so*" -type f -execdir chmod 755 '{}' \;`

- In debian upstream, a few files were moved from ceph-base to other pkgs:
 - ceph-volume files moved to ceph-osd
 - compressor and crypto files moved to ceph-common
 - lib/systemd/system/ceph.target, etc/logrotate.d/ceph and etc/sysconfig/ceph moved to ceph-common

Built and included in an ISO. Before we can enable this in the build we'll need to optimize this (minimize the packages/features built) so that we can build this without having to modify the pkgbuilder. I'm ok with submitting this to enable using the package for integration and optimize with a future commit.

Care to explain a bit more? It seems to be a new service - does it add some new attack surface? Does it need new ports?

Thanks, your question makes sense to me.
The ingress daemon, which is applied by something like [1], as described in [2], needs two more ports:

1. frontend_port
2. monitoring_port

These two ports are required by haproxy to accept incoming requests and for monitoring purposes (check the health status), so we need make TripleO aware about this service and properly setup the firewall rules.
As long the ports used by this service are passed to the overcloud deployment process, (or are defined in the tht CephIngress daemon tht specification) [3] (which is still WIP) the 'firewall_rules' ansible role is supposed to be run and the "attack surface" should be covered as per all the other services.

I'm going to make this part more clear/explicit in the next PS! Thanks Cedric for your comment!

Thanks, fixing the nit in the next PS.
The ingress daemon is a component made by 2 containers provided by Ceph: haproxy + keepalived.
Haproxy requires the ports I mentioned in this PS, and they are exposed on the network where the frontend vip is reserved.

In particular, if you have something like the following:

- name: Create the ingress Daemon spec definition for nfs
  become: true
  ceph_mkspec:
    service_type: ingress
    cluster: "{{ tripleo_cephadm_cluster }}"
    apply: true
    hosts: "{{ _hosts | unique }}"
    render_path: "{{ tripleo_cephadm_spec_home }}"
    spec:
      backend_service: nfs.nfs
      frontend_port: "{{ tripleo_cephadm_nfs_ingress_frontend_port }}"
      monitor_port: "{{ tripleo_cephadm_nfs_ingress_monitor_port }}"
      virtual_ip: "{{ tripleo_cephadm_nfs_ingress_vip | default('0.0.0.0') }}"
      virtual_interface_networks: "{{ tripleo_cephadm_ceph_nfs_address_block }}"

you can see in the spec dict we have both the VIP and the associated network (it can be a composable network, like StorageNFS).
Networks and vips are already provisioned in this process after metal (networkv2 takes care about the networking definition/creation).
At this stage we don't have any firewall rule applied, as it will be done during the overcloud deployment (like any other Ceph component).
This is really lovely! That will solve a long standing issue we get regularly reported.

REVIEW_GUIDELINES.rst.message: don't be scared
there's no scorn
i think we've gotten pretty good at this - and if there's a gap it's not laziness
it's not so bad
abusive sounds like a trigger word to me - it's just cat photos and self driving car footage - chill out.
+1 agree, let's definitely remove this metaphor
I dropped this because it said manpages, but maybe there's still more to say about docs...

We could add a checklist for docs e.g.:

  Changes that add, remove or modify a config option must update the config file(s) and the deployment guide.

  Changes that modify API behavior should update the API docs.

  Changes that introduce a new feature should usually add an overview doc for the feature.

  Changes that introduce or modify a development pattern may need to update development guidelines.

we ought to be discouraging this kind of language in reviews, regardless of the quality of the patch - it's likely to be interpreted as snarky e.g. the use of "even" implies there are other shortcomings. "Did you run this?" would be less loaded, but "I ran this and it failed in the following way" is far less aggressive/accusatory.
We need to be careful when straying into reviewing the author rather than reviewing the code: e.g. "Your patch needs to be improved in the following ways..." vs "You didn't make enough effort".
Full stop. Then, "A thorough..." (only one "u").
It may not be realistic for every reviewer to test other people's patches in a production environment. I wouldn't want this comment to put someone off leaving a review.
a reference to SAIO here would be good
s/prod/production/

I feel like it might also be good to praise the review that's like

> I tested this in ``environment`` and it does what it says, but it breaks ``some relatively obscure workflow`` because of X which Ys then Z.

Bonus points when you're prepared to explain why the obscure workflow is in fact critical to your use-case :-)

I think I preferred "your" -- yes, it becomes "our" shared code, but I felt like the point was to give the contributor some distinct sense of ownership. Otherwise, the "when contributing changes to Swift" lead-in feels a little odd.

I'd keep "our bugs", though -- once it's merged, the code is on all of us. Any bugs that came with it are not yours alone, though we'll likely want your input to make sure we're not horribly breaking the feature to fix the bug. These are two of the big up-shots to contributing upstream:

* Your code has a high likelihood of being exercised at a scale you're not at yet -- so you'll have a higher degree of confidence that it will continue to work as you grow.
* When there's a bug, it's all of ours to fix. You may still need to make the case for it, and you probably ought to be involved in the fix, but you'll have a great group of smart, helpful people backing you up.

or, avoid any implication of ownership and refer to "the code"

  When contributing changes to Swift, remember that the code is running - in production - at scale - and bugs cannot hide.

the os-vif and neutron changes are what actually prevent that.

this change was intended to make the libvirt driver rely on os-vif to plug the vif into ovs. libvirt would still create the tap and set the mtu and mac as it/qemu normally does but

the ethernet type which is just a tap device not connected to anything is refered to as a  Generic ethernet connection in libvirt docs which is why i called it generic on the os-vif side.

While I haven't heard of a security report re: OVN, we have experienced reports from customers about network interruption during live migrations because the ports have not been wired before the VM is paused for the memory copy. Will this patch also be applicable for OVN in the following 'fixes' that describes that issue?

it applies to ovn in that it will elminate the race for any solution that uses hybrid_plug=false
which include ovn. it is not a security issue in that case but it should help reduce packet loss
provided ovn will recaulate the flows and install them. if it waits for the openflow id to be populated in the ovs db before installing some or all of the flows it wont reduce the time it take to setup the flows at all.

as you know we do not provdie any sla or guarentees for packet loss during a live migration to our customer upstream or downstream. fundementally we can never guarentee there will be 0 packet loss and if a network solution depend on the device being present on the datapath before it can program the flows then this change will not alter that requirement. it will simply move the creation fo the port in the contol plane earlier.

for ml2/ovs there is no depenciy (anymore) on the port also being present on the dataplane to start installing the flows in the contol plane. i am not sure how ovn generates its flows but if it use the of_port id as part of its flow rules it will need to wait until libvirt creates the tap defice to install those flows that need it. so it really comes down to the internal of the SDN contolers openflow pipeline which is out of scope of the nova release notes.

clear as mud i know but that is really the best we can do.

our upstream users and down stream custoemr should be aware of the fact that no sla applies once an instance is live migrated and that all we can do is make a best effort attempt to minimse the impact within reason.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Remove code to explicitly disable cinder image-volume cache from .zuul.yaml.

In Zuul and the local environment, LCM incomplete timeout is observed in SOL functional test cases. 
This failure happens as image_volume_cache by default is enabled, and the cache volume remains during Termination, this causes Heat stack deletion failure without erasing volume type. 
In the local environment, when disabling image_volume_cache in cinder.conf, it resolves LCM timeout issue, but the same solution seems irrelevant when applied in controller-tacker as no cinder directory exists. Hence revert .zuul.yaml changes.

The big question is, how do we force the fake driver to return success or failure? This approach does 'ls /path/image' to determine success. That works for this UT.

But, for other UT and for functional tests, we should be able to download some Glance image successfully and still fail the programming in the fake driver. That means we should either delete the downloaded file or mock the downloading function to not do that. Does anybody see any catches there?

 bdf_lengths = [2, 2, 1]

 if all([len(bdf_val) == length and int(bdf_val, 16) <= limit

Are you going to implement the event handler for the deleted/added ports?

that would be a good followup, or checking the original comments suggested way with ordered event handling (https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/services/trunk/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovsdb_handler.py#L212-L220 )

Right. This sleep is just a placebo. We had examples, in customers, were the port was added to the bridge just before the trunk services deletes the bridge.

There are two approaches, both necessary:
- Make the change in os-vif: this is the safest way. In the "_plug_vhostuser" method, create a single OVS DB transaction to ensure the bridge is created and create the port. That ensures nobody can delete the bridge when the port is being added.
- Here:
1) remove the sleep
2) monitor the ovsdb and check when the port has been added
3) just before deleting the trunk bridge, check if the port is present again. If so, exit the method

Hi @Rabi, maybe you can get more insights from https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2051376 . The thing is that maybe this fix is like killing a fly with a cannon, but basically the container tripleo configs for step 5 remain after the UC upgrade (while for any other step the configs belonging to deprecated services get removed). This causes the deployment tasks to start up nova_compute, nova_wait_for_compute_service and mistral_db_populate containers during the OSP17 deployment steps. And as nova_wait_for_compute service expects nova_conductor to be up, the upgrade fails...but none of these three services should be starting up.
This fix solves the issue and the container's configs get recreated, but maybe we should try to address the problem per se and find out why only those configs remain. WDYT?
